practiceQuestions.question: In the sentence "Odipo beto lum", what makes lum function as a complement?
options: It is a subject modified by a verb
It appears before the verb in SVO order
It directly receives the action of the verb beto
It acts as an indirect beneficiary
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘Lum’ is the direct object receiving the action of the verb ‘beto’ (carry).

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following most accurately represents the complete syntactic structure of the sentence "Odipo miyo Olum luth"?
options: Subject + Object + Verb + Recipient
Verb + Subject + Direct Object + Indirect Complement
Subject + Verb + Indirect Complement + Direct Object
Subject + Verb + Adverbial + Object
practiceQuestions.explanation: The structure is Subject (Odipo) + Verb (miyo) + Indirect Complement (Olum) + Direct Object (luth).

practiceQuestions.question: In the clause "Olum kawo luth kuom Odipo", the phrase "kuom Odipo" semantically expresses:
options: The affected object
The source of transfer
The recipient of the action
An optional adverbial of time
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘Kuom Odipo’ indicates the source of the transfer: the person from whom ‘luth’ is taken.

practiceQuestions.question: In which of the following constructions is the complement essential for maintaining syntactic and semantic completeness?
options: Odipo biro
Olum wuok
Odipo tong’o yien
Nyathi nindo
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘Yien’ (tree/branch) is a necessary direct complement for the verb ‘tong’o’ (cut).

practiceQuestions.question: Which best describes the dual-object relationship in the sentence “Nyathi miyo mingi adita”?
options: One object acts as both recipient and theme
One is a recipient (mother), the other a transferred item (basket)
There is only a single compound object
The direct object precedes the indirect
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘Mingi’ (mother) is the recipient; ‘adita’ (basket) is the transferred theme.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is the word “kuon” in “Odipo gi Olum chamo kuon” classified as a complement?
options: It introduces a prepositional phrase
It modifies the verb in tense
It is the direct object receiving the verb action
It acts as the subject of the sentence

practiceQuestions.question: Which sentence correctly demonstrates the use of a prepositional indirect complement?
options: Nyathi chamo kuon
Olum kawo luth kuom Odipo
Odipo miyo Olum luth
Amiyo barua Olum
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘Kuom Odipo’ is a prepositional phrase marking an indirect complement (source).

practiceQuestions.question: What syntactic rule is demonstrated by the phrase “Amiyo Olum barua”?
options: The indirect complement must be postverbal but final
Direct objects cannot precede indirect complements
The indirect complement precedes the direct object in a transfer verb
Verbs in Dholuo require only one object at a time
practiceQuestions.explanation: Dholuo places the indirect complement (‘Olum’) before the direct object (‘barua’) in ditransitive constructions.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is “dhoot” in both “Olum yawo dhoot” and “Odipo loro dhoot” an example of a direct complement?
options: It is always accompanied by an adverb
It serves as the recipient in a passive construction
It is the direct receiver of two different transitive actions
It modifies the subject rather than the verb

practiceQuestions.question: According to Dholuo morphosyntactic rules, what happens when an indirect complement is introduced by "kuom"?
options: The subject and verb must be reversed
It marks a prepositional recipient in receptive constructions
The direct object is eliminated
The action becomes reflexive
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘Kuom’ introduces a prepositional phrase indicating the recipient or source of the action.
